name: Benin
introduction: Present day Benin was the site of Dahomey a West African kingdom that rose to prominence in about 1600 and over the next two and a half centuries became a regional power largely based on its slave trade. Coastal areas of Dahomey began to be controlled by the French in the second half of the 19th century; the entire kingdom was conquered by 1894. French Dahomey achieved independence in 1960; it changed its name to the Republic of Benin in 1975. ++ A succession of military governments ended in 1972 with the rise to power of Mathieu KEREKOU and the establishment of a government based on Marxist-Leninist principles. A move to representative government began in 1989. Two years later free elections ushered in former Prime Minister Nicephore SOGLO as president marking the first successful transfer of power in Africa from a dictatorship to a democracy. KEREKOU was returned to power by elections held in 1996 and 2001 though some irregularities were alleged. KEREKOU stepped down at the end of his second term in 2006 and was succeeded by Thomas YAYI Boni a political outsider and independent who won a second five-year term in March 2011. Patrice TALON a wealthy businessman took office in 2016 after campaigning to restore public confidence in the government.
overview: 'Benin a French-speaking West African nation is a birthplace of the vodun (or “voodoo”) religion and home to the former Dahomey Kingdom from circa 1600–1900. In Abomey Dahomey''s former capital the Historical Museum occupies two royal palaces with bas-reliefs recounting the kingdom’s past and a throne mounted on human skulls. To the north Pendjari National Park offers safaris with elephants hippos and lions.'

languages.name: Aja (Benin)
languages.area: Southwest on Mono River. Primarily in Couffo Province (formerly north Mono Province), Aplahoué, Djakotomè, Dogbo, Klouékanmè, Lalo, and Tovinklin Subprefectures; Mono Province (formerly south Mono Province) Athiémè, Comè, and Houéyogbé Subprefectures; Zou Province, Djidja and Agbangnizoun Subprefectures, Cotonou and many towns in the south, villages mixed with other language groups. Also in Togo.

languages.name: American Sign Language
languages.area: Also in Barbados, Benin, Bolivia, Burkina Faso, Canada, Central African Republic, Chad, China, Côte d’Ivoire, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Gabon, Ghana, Jamaica, Kenya, Madagascar, Mauritania, Nigeria, Philippines, Singapore, Togo, Zimbabwe.

languages.name: Aguna
languages.area: Zou Province, Djidja Subprefecture, Agouna village area.

languages.name: Ayizo Gbe
languages.area: Mono and Atlantique provinces.

languages.name: Baatonum
languages.area: Central, north, Borgou Province. Also in Nigeria.

languages.name: Biali
languages.area: Atakora Province, Materi Subprefecture; Borgou Province, Ouessi Subprefecture. Also in Burkina Faso.

languages.name: Anii
languages.area: Both sides of Togo-Benin border; south Aracora Province, Bassila Subprefecture. Also in Togo.

languages.name: Notre
languages.area: Atakora Province, Tanguiéta Subprefecture, northwest, north, and northeast of Tanguiéta town, including Yarka section northeast.

languages.name: Somba-Siawari
languages.area: Morobe Province, Finschhafen District, Central Huon Peninsula, south of Cromwell Range, Burum River valley and west slopes of Kuat River. 30 villages. Many in towns, 1,000 in Lae, scattered in Port Moresby area. 3 airstrips: Ogeramnang, Mindik, Nomanene.

languages.name: Tchumbuli
languages.area: Département des Collines, Save and Ouessi subprefectures, 3 villages: Okounfo, Edaningbe, and Gbede.

languages.name: Boko (Benin)
languages.area: Borgu Province. Also in Nigeria.

languages.name: Ede Cabe
languages.area: Borgou Province, Tchaourou Subprefecture; Zou Province, Savè and Ouèssè subprefectures.

languages.name: Ci Gbe
languages.area: Mono Province, Lalo Subprefecture.

languages.name: Anufo
languages.area: Northeast, Wawjayga area. Also in Benin, Togo.

languages.name: Dendi (Benin)
languages.area: Atakora and Borgou provinces, along Niger River, Medru River to Nigeria border, down to Kandi. Many at Djogou and towns in the north. Also in Nigeria.

languages.name: Zarma
languages.area: Southwest. Also in Burkina Faso, Mali, Nigeria.

languages.name: Lukpa
languages.area: West Djougou and border areas, Atakora Province. Primarily Kémérida area. Also in Togo.

languages.name: Ewe
languages.area: Southeast corner. Also in Togo.

languages.name: Foodo
languages.area: Atakora Province, Ouake Subprefecture, Semere town. Also in Ghana.

languages.name: Fon
languages.area: Zou Province, Atlantic Province, south Abomey-Calavi and Ouidah Subprefectures; Littoral Province, Cotonou. Interspersed with other groups south and in towns north. Also in Togo.

languages.name: French
languages.area: Also in Algeria, Andorra, Austria, Belgium, Benin, Burkina Faso, Burundi, Cambodia, Cameroon, Canada, Central African Republic, Chad, Comoros, Congo, Côte d’Ivoire, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Djibouti, Equatorial Guinea, French Guiana, French Polynesia, Gabon, Guadeloupe, Guinea, Haiti, India, Israel, Italy, Lebanon, Libya, Luxembourg, Madagascar, Mali, Martinique, Mauritania, Mauritius, Mayotte, Monaco, Morocco, Mozambique, New Caledonia, Niger, Philippines, Puerto Rico, Réunion, Rwanda, Saint Pierre and Miquelon, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, Seychelles, South Africa, Switzerland, Togo, Tunisia, United Arab Emirates, United Kingdom, United States, U.S. Virgin Islands, Vanuatu, Wallis and Futuna.

languages.name: Borgu Fulfulde
languages.area: Atakora and Borgou provinces, villages, and encampments; Borgou region, Bakuure north of N’Dali; central and south Borgou region, Parakou area, Korakuure; north, Atacora region, Djougoure, from Djougou north to Burkina border. May extend west into north Togo; Tchabankeere in Zou region. Also in Nigeria, Togo.

languages.name: Western Niger Fulfulde
languages.area: West, Burkina Faso border east to Dogondoutchi area. Also in Benin, Burkina Faso.

languages.name: Ga
languages.area: Southeast, Accra coast area.

languages.name: Defi Gbe
languages.area: Southeast corner, Oueme Province, Seme-Kpodji Subprefecture between Oueme River north, Cotonou-Porto-Novo railroad west, Gulf of Guinea south, and into Nigeria east.

languages.name: Gbesi Gbe
languages.area: Atlantic Province, Kpomasse, Alada, and Tori-Bossito Subprefectures, individual and mixed villages; Mono Province, Bopa Subprefecture along Lake Aheme.

languages.name: Eastern Xwla Gbe
languages.area: Southeast along coast, Oueme Province, Seme-Kpodji Subprefecture.

languages.name: Gen
languages.area: Southeast, Maritime region. Also in Benin.

languages.name: Ngangam
languages.area: Savana region, Oti Prefecture, Gando-Namoni, Mogou, Koumongou, and Kountouri areas. Also in Benin.

languages.name: Gun
languages.area: Southeast, Weme Province, Akpro-Misserete, Avrankou, Adjara, and Porto-Novo subprefectures. Also in Nigeria.

languages.name: Gourmanchéma
languages.area: East, Gourma, Tapoa, Gnagna, Komandjari, Yagha, and Kompienga provinces, below scrub land that blends into the Sahara. Also in Benin, Niger, Togo.

languages.name: Hausa
languages.area: Sokoto, Kaduna, Katsina, Kano, Bauchi, Jigawa, Zamfara, Kebbi, and Gombe states. Spoken as L2 in north. Also in Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Chad, Congo, Eritrea, Germany, Ghana, Niger, Sudan, Togo.

languages.name: Ede Ica
languages.area: Zou Province, Bante Subprefecture.

languages.name: Ede Idaca
languages.area: Collines Province (north half of former Zou Province), Dassa-Zoume and Glazoué Subprefectures.

languages.name: Ifè
languages.area: South, Northeast Plateau region, Ogou and Est-Mono prefectures. Atakpamé, Kamina, Dadja, and Ese-Ana are main centers. Also in Benin.

languages.name: Ede Ije
languages.area: Plateau Province (north part of former Oueme Province), Pobe and Ketou subprefectures; Zou Province, Ouihni Subprefecture. Rural districts between Ketou and Pobe towns, westward to Oueme River; villages in Zou Province, Zogbodome Subprefecture, south of Zogbodome town.

languages.name: Kabiyè
languages.area: Kara region, mostly Kozah and Binah prefectures. 2/3 in Central and Plateau regions, Sotouboua, Blitta, Kloto, Ogou, Amlame, Wawa, and Haho prefectures. Also in Benin, Ghana.

languages.name: Tem
languages.area: Kara region, Bafilo Subprefecture; Central region, Tchoudjo and Sotouboua prefectures; Bafilo, Sokode, and Sotouboua are main centers; Plateau region near Badou. Also in Benin, Ghana.

languages.name: Kotafon Gbe
languages.area: Mono Province, mainly Lokassa and Athieme subprefectures; Bopa Subprefecture north and south of Bopa along Lake Aheme; Grand Popo Subprefecture, north of Grand-Popo, a few villages.

languages.name: Lama (Togo)
languages.area: Kara region, Kande and Doufelgou prefectures; 50% of the population in Central and Plateau regions, Sotouboua, Ogou, and Haho prefectures; important minority in Lomé. Also in Benin, Ghana.

languages.name: Mokole
languages.area: Borgou Province, Kandi and villages north and east.

languages.name: Mandinka
languages.area: Southeast and south central. Also in Gambia, Guinea-Bissau.

languages.name: Mossi
languages.area: Central Ouagadougou area; widespread. Also in Benin, Côte d’Ivoire, Ghana, Mali, Senegal, Togo.

languages.name: Mbelime
languages.area: Atakora Province, Cobly Subprefecture, and 5 villages in Boukombe Subprefecture.

languages.name: Maxi Gbe
languages.area: Collines Province (formerly north Zou Province), Dassa-Zoume, Savalou, Bante, Glazoue, and Ouessi subprefectures. Also in Togo.

languages.name: Southern Nago
languages.area: Southeast, Plateau Province (formerly north Weme Province), Ketou, Pobe, Adja-Ouere, Ifangni, and Sakete subprefectures.

languages.name: Kura Ede Nago
languages.area: Donga Province (formerly south Atakora Province), Bassila Subprefecture. Aledjo Koura is main center.

languages.name: Nateni
languages.area: Atakora Province. Natemba in Toukountouna District; Tayaba in Tanguiéta District; Kuntemba in Kobly, Matiri, and Tanguiéta districts; Okoma in Tanguiéta and Kouandé districts. Tayakou is center of traditional beliefs and practices.

languages.name: Yom
languages.area: Atakora Province, Djougou area.

languages.name: Koyraboro Senni Songhai
languages.area: Southeast, along Niger River from Gourma Rharous, east of Timbuktu, through Bourem, Goa, and Ansongo to Mali-Niger border. Believed to border Kaado (Zarma) [dje] in Niger.

languages.name: Miyobe
languages.area: Atakora Province. Also in Togo.

languages.name: Saxwe Gbe
languages.area: Mono Province.

languages.name: Ditammari
languages.area: Atakora Province, Boukombe and Natitingou subprefectures; along Djougou-Parakou road. Also in Togo.

languages.name: Tofin Gbe
languages.area: Atlantique Province, So-Ava Subprefecture.

languages.name: Kyanga
languages.area: Kebbi state, Geshuru, Kaele, Saufu, and Tuni villages west of Illo; Boko villages of Maze, Samia, Baikinrua, Pisa. Also in Benin.

languages.name: Waci Gbe
languages.area: Main centers Vogan, Tabligbo, Attitigon. Also in Benin.

languages.name: Weme Gbe
languages.area: Weme and Atlantic provinces.

languages.name: Waama
languages.area: Atakora Province, at least 20 villages. Natitingou is cultural center. Several thousand in Cotonou, Parakou area, and west Nigeria.

languages.name: Northern Nago
languages.area: Donga Province (formerly south Atakora Province), Bassila Subprefecture south and west of Bassila town, Bante Subprefecture south of Bassila along route RNIE3. Also in Togo.

languages.name: Xwela Gbe
languages.area: Mono Province, Come Subprefecture near Lake Aheme, southernmost Bopa Subprefecture; Atlantic Province, Kpomasse and Ouidah subprefectures.

languages.name: Yoruba
languages.area: Most of Oyo, Ogun, Ondo, Osun, Kwara, and Lagos states; Kogi state, west LGAs. Also in Benin, Sierra Leone, Togo, United Kingdom, United States.
